title: האפוקליפסה
content: לבשתי שמלה צהובה. זו הייתה האפוקליפסה. הצלחנו לצוד תפוחי אדמה, ובצלים. האפקוליפסה, מעולם לא נראה יפה יותר. התהלכתי על השאנז אליזה, אבל הם נראו כדיזינגוף בואכה בזל. לבשתי שמלה צהובה. הייתי הרה יותר ויותר, מרגע לרגע. האם היה זה ערן, שהלך לצידי? האם לו הריתי? האפוקליפסה מעולם לא נראה טוב יותר למרות שאף אחד לא רצה לאכול תפוחי אדמה עם בצל. לי, הם נראו כמו חלום.

echoes.author: Edgar Allan Poe
echoes.context: From his poem "A Dream Within a Dream," reflecting on the transient and illusory nature of reality and perception, resonating with the new entry's dreamlike disorientation and questioning of what is real.
echoes.text: All that we see or seem Is but a dream within a dream.

echoes.author: Kintsugi Philosophy
echoes.context: An ancient Japanese art form and philosophy that celebrates the flaws and repairs of broken objects, finding beauty and value in their history of breakage and resilience, mirroring the entry's 'apocalypse never looked more beautiful' and growth from damage.
echoes.text: Treat breakage and repair as part of an object's history, not something to disguise, mending with gold.

echoes.author: Henry David Thoreau
echoes.context: From "Walden," describing a two-year experiment in simple living close to nature, focusing on self-sufficiency and confronting life's fundamental truths, mirroring the new entry's 'hunting' for potatoes and onions and return to basic sustenance.
echoes.text: I went to the woods because I wished to live deliberately, to front only the essential facts of life.

echoes.author: Heraclitus
echoes.context: A core tenet of the pre-Socratic Greek philosopher Heraclitus, who posited that everything is in a constant state of flux and transformation, which resonates with the new entry's description of a world undergoing radical, albeit beautiful, change.
echoes.text: The only constant is change.

echoes.author: John of Patmos
echoes.context: The final book of the New Testament, depicting a prophetic vision of the end times, judgment, and the creation of a new heaven and earth, offering a direct parallel to the 'apocalypse' theme while also hinting at renewal and growth.
echoes.text: I saw a new heaven and a new earth: for the first heaven and the first earth were passed away.

echoes.author: Frida Kahlo
echoes.context: The diary entries and paintings of Mexican artist Frida Kahlo are deeply introspective, exploring her physical suffering, identity, and complex personal life, often with surreal and vibrant imagery that finds powerful expression amidst pain, similar to the new entry's vivid descriptions of a personal apocalypse, pregnancy, and the yellow dress.
echoes.text: I paint my own reality. The only thing I know is that I paint because I need to.

content: כמו שפרויד אמר, תחושות פיזיות באמת יכולות לעורר חלום ואני הלכתי לישון עם צורך קל לעשות קקי. עברתי בחווה מבודדת, ונכנסתי אליה על מנת להשתמש בשירותים. בדלת הכניסה, הצגתי את עצמי וביקשתי רשות והגבר אמר כמובן. בעודי ישובה על האסלה הוא נכנס, החליף גליל של נייר טואלט, והתעסק עם דברים. בחלוף זמן מה, נכנסה גם אשתו והתיישבה מולי. רציתי לבקש פרטיות, אבל להישאר מנומסת. לא ידעתי אם זה קטע של כפריים. אמרתי, הממ. אוקיי, זה לא שאתם מפריעים, אני פשוט מוטרדת. בחיים לא ייצא לי ככה.

echoes.author: Roman citizens
echoes.context: Unlike modern standards, privacy in ancient Roman public restrooms was largely nonexistent. These communal spaces served as social hubs where people conducted business and gossip, highlighting a stark contrast in cultural norms regarding personal space.
echoes.text: Imagine public latrines where dozens of citizens shared marble benches, side-by-side, engaging in conversation while attending to their natural calls.

echoes.author: Desiderius Erasmus
echoes.context: This influential etiquette guide from the Renaissance aimed to civilize European society, offering strict rules for everything from table manners to personal hygiene, reflecting a conscious effort to define and enforce social boundaries.
echoes.text: Erasmus provided detailed instructions on proper conduct, including how to discreetly manage bodily functions and maintain a polite demeanor in social settings.

echoes.author: Captain James Cook
echoes.context: European explorers like Captain Cook frequently documented their observations of indigenous cultures, often expressing confusion or judgment over practices that differed from their own, illustrating the universal challenge of cross-cultural understanding.
echoes.text: Upon landing, we often encountered customs and social behaviors that defied our European expectations, leading to moments of mutual bewilderment.

echoes.author: Various Architects & Sociologists
echoes.context: For centuries, most homes, even among the wealthy, had open floor plans where family and servants shared spaces. The gradual emergence of distinct, private rooms reflected a changing societal emphasis on personal boundaries and solitude.
echoes.text: The rise of specialized rooms like bedrooms and bathrooms marked a significant shift towards valuing individual privacy within the domestic sphere.

echoes.author: Franz Kafka
echoes.context: Kafka's novel explores themes of absurdity, alienation, and the individual's powerlessness against opaque bureaucratic systems, resonating with feelings of being exposed and misunderstood in illogical situations.
echoes.text: Josef K. finds himself arrested and tried by an inaccessible authority, grappling with bewildering procedures and a constant sense of violation of his personal autonomy.

echoes.author: Michel de Montaigne
echoes.context: Montaigne, writing in an era less concerned with physical privacy, passionately advocated for an internal 'back shop'—a space of mental solitude and self-reflection—as essential for personal freedom and authenticity, even amidst societal demands.
echoes.text: We must reserve a back shop all our own, entirely free, in which to set up our true liberty, and our principal retreat and solitude.

content: על אף האמונה המוצקה בברכותיי,  מצאתי את עצמי נאלצת לספור אותן. חלמתי שאני נכשלת בכל האוניברסיטאות. חלמתי שאני בונה קופסאות קטנות, קטנטנות, פיציות ממש מנייר a4. כל הדיבורים האלו על אלוהים, וחוק, ועוני, רוקנו אותי ממש מתוכן. יצא לי המילוי כמו מכרית ישנה, ונשאר לשכב שם בשמש. בחלום עברתי דרך הגנים למוסד היחיד שניאות לקבלני: המכללה לאדריכלות נוף.

echoes.author: Ecclesiastes
echoes.context: This ancient biblical passage expresses a cyclical view of history and human experience, suggesting that fundamental truths and events recur, making reinterpretation a key to new insight.
echoes.text: What has been will be again, what has been done will be done again; there is nothing new under the sun.

echoes.author: Charles Dickens
echoes.context: The famous plea from the orphan Oliver Twist, embodying the desperate situation of neglected children in Victorian England.
echoes.text: Please, sir, I want some more.

echoes.author: Walt Whitman
echoes.context: Whitman's celebration of the individual self, acknowledging and embracing the vastness and often contradictory nature of human experience and identity.
echoes.text: Do I contradict myself? Very well then I contradict myself, (I am large, I contain multitudes.)

echoes.author: Rainer Maria Rilke
echoes.context: Rilke advises patience and introspection for an aspiring poet, suggesting that answers to deep questions emerge through living experience, akin to a natural blooming process.
echoes.text: Live the questions now. Perhaps you will then gradually, without noticing it, live along some distant day into the answer.

echoes.author: T.S. Eliot
echoes.context: Eliot argues that true originality isn't a rejection of the past, but a re-evaluation and re-ordering of tradition through the new work.
echoes.text: The existing monuments form an ideal order among themselves, which is modified by the introduction of the new (the really new) work of art among them.

echoes.author: Marshall McLuhan
echoes.context: McLuhan theorized that the form of a medium embeds itself in the message, altering how the message is perceived and understood, fundamentally shaping society.
echoes.text: The medium is the message.

content: ספיר סבורה שכל מה שניתן להגיד כבר נאמר, לכן על מנת לומר דבר מה בעל חשיבות כל שצריך לעשות הוא לנסח מחדש. אז היא אומרת: ׳יומני היקר; מוריסי היה אבא שלי, האמטיוי היה אמא שלי. בשנת 92 הותירו אותי מולו ולא בדקו מה קורה עם זה במשך חמש עשרה שנה. כבנה הנטוש של מארי אנטואנט, גם אני גדלתי פרא׳. ספיר זורקת שמות. היא מרגישה חיבור עז לעונות השנה, ומחויבות לאביב. היא תוהה אם תפרח בזמן. היא תוהה אם בתור ביתו של מוריסי גם היא היורשת של ביישנות, גסה בצורה נפשעת.

echoes.author: Ecclesiastes (traditional author, Solomon)
echoes.context: This ancient wisdom text expresses a profound sense of the cyclical nature of existence, where human actions and experiences are endlessly repeated.
echoes.text: What has been will be again, what has been done will be done again; there is nothing new under the sun.

echoes.author: Louis XVII (via historical event)
echoes.context: The son of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette, he was separated from his family during the French Revolution and died in prison due to neglect and harsh conditions, his fate a symbol of an innocent life 'grown wild' by abandonment.
echoes.text: Abandoned and left to grow wild in the Temple prison, a tragic consequence of the revolution.

echoes.author: Mary Shelley
echoes.context: As the daughter of radical intellectuals Mary Wollstonecraft and William Godwin, Mary Shelley's identity was profoundly shaped by her unconventional upbringing and the intellectual legacy she inherited and reinterpreted, much like Sapir's self-identification through cultural figures.
echoes.text: The offspring of philosophical and literary giants, crafting narratives of creation and identity.

echoes.author: Ecclesiastes (traditional author, Solomon)
echoes.context: This verse reflects on the natural rhythm of life, emphasizing that there is an appointed time for everything, echoing Sapir's contemplation of 'blooming in time' with the seasons.
echoes.text: To everything there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven.

echoes.author: Walt Whitman
echoes.context: In 'Song of Myself,' Whitman embraces a multifaceted and often contradictory self, a 'multitude' of experiences and traits, resonating with Sapir's query about inheriting conflicting qualities like 'shyness, terribly crude.'
echoes.text: Do I contradict myself? Very well then I contradict myself, (I am large, I contain multitudes.)

echoes.author: Pablo Picasso
echoes.context: This famous quote, often attributed to Picasso, encapsulates the idea that originality in art and thought often comes not from pure invention, but from creatively reinterpreting, 'stealing' from, and re-contextualizing existing ideas, aligning with Sapir's belief in rephrasing as the path to significance.
echoes.text: Good artists copy, great artists steal.
